history.text: hELLO
Hi!
Have you seen Batman Begins?
I can't believe I haven't, what with all of these big names in the cast as well as Christopher Nolan as the director
I think I've seen some scenes but not the entire movie. Quite surprised on Rotten Tomatoes it received an 84%
It's hard to do both a comic-book movie and a real life drama at the same time
Is Batman Begins the only series?
Agree
The first of the new reboot series
I'm not familiar with Ra al Ghul or Scarecrow
Awesome to have Christian Bale and Liam Neeson playing in one movie.
I must have seen a couple of scenes in passing, because I do remember Bruce Wayne being terrified in a cave with bats
Bruce was attacked by bats? I didn't know that.
His fear of bats also lead them into the alleyway where his parents were killed, so I can see how he'd feel guilty about being afraid of them
Oh he fell into a dry well
Are you referring to Bruce as a child?
Said Joe Chill murdered his parents.
Yes, but only because they were outside at a bad time because Bruce (as a kid) was scared of the "bats" in a show
I'm quite surprised this movie received a score of A on CinemaScore.
I can believe it. I like how you can actually relate to the arguments of the villians, like Gotham City being deserving of a purge
Bruce seemed to be a troubled person. He traveled to know the truth of what's happening but in the end he ended up burning down the temple.
Hmmm... So Bruce's actual teachers turned out to be evil, or to have at least come to a very wrong conclusion so he had to end up being against them.
His parents were murdered and he seemed to be lost not knowing who to trust. I think he even had a hard time trusting himselk.
I'd like to see Liam Neeson as this Ducard/Ra'a al Chul
I think Liam Neeson is a great actor and he knows how to act.
Rachel was rescued by Batman
So, the movie's villians later in the film, like Dr. Crane, claim to be trained by the same people who trained Bruce. I wonder if it's true
Woah, and Ducard, who Bruce saved from the temple burning, is the REAL Ra al Chul
I think Dr. Crane is a crooked villain who only wants to cause harms but in this scene he meets Batman. I think scene 3 is the turning point of this movie.
Definitely. You start to question everything you thought you knew.
With Gordon being one of the "few" honest cops left in Gotham, it sure drive home how alone Batman must feel with all of these questions about who is actually any good
Scene two says 14 years later so saying Bruce had grown up and I wonder who trained him to become Batman in scene 3.
I think that for those 14 years he was just stewing and being angsty. Then he got his training in Bhutan
Then he killed who he thought was the leader, only to realize that it was the fake leader
What is the Ra's al Ghul in scene 3 and why does it matter to Batman? Is it related to the murder of his parents and is Batman seeking for revenge?
That's why he burned down the temple.
Ra al Ghul was supposedly the one who taught him everything in Bhutan, whom he thought that he had killed in the fire
But later we're now learning that the man he killed in the fire was just a stand-in for the real Ra a Ghul, so the real one (who wants to purge all of Gotham) is still out and about
Ra al Ghul actually showed up to Batman's birthday how odd that was and is he the bad buy?
